There's been a lot of concern over Harry Potter books in school...(m)

My son goes to a Christian school and they are not allowed to read or do a book report on Harry Potter this year. I was just wondering if anyone has had a similar experience or have your children read Harry Potter and you find there's really not anything wrong with it? My son isn't upset about it and neither am I - I guess I am just curious what's in the books.



My nursery bookshelves contain many other equally-imaginative (and better-written) children's fantasies....

Although Rowling's books stand up pretty well among them, in terms of both the quality of the language and the morality of the underlying themes, I prefer E. Nesbitt's charming fantasies, and for that matter Mary Norton's and Alan Garner's. So does Anne (my DD8).

BUT, even a child likes to be able to discuss what she's reading with her peers, and most of them have never heard of a Psammead. Anne became interested in Harry Potter when her cronies did. One of them gave her the first two books for her birthday, and Anne was won over. I wasn't: I read all four Harry Potter books. While they strained my suspension of disbelief and pushed my hot buttons regarding cultural assumptions about educational norms, I found them morally unobjectionable.

What finally won me over to the fans of Harry Potter, was an event that occurred recently at Anne's school. She had gotten into a spat with an unpopular child -- a child whom Anne had been asked to befriend by both me and her headmistress. Anne had been feeling the strain of standing up for "Joe" against her close friends who wanted to shun him. I was expressing sympathy with her, when she interrupted me and fetched "Goblet of Fire", saying that she wanted to read me something. Here's what she read (I am paraphrasing from memory): "Today, a we lost one of our own. Remember Cedric Diggory! Remember Cedric whenever you are tempted to do what is easy instead of what is right". I asked her what that meant -- what she planned to do; and she told me she intended to go on being "Joe's" friend.

Jesus told us, "by their fruits you may know them". Harry Potter is teaching Anne to choose what is *right* over what is *easy* -- that is the "fruit" of these stories.
